titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Arthur W. Kramer sound recording collection, 1958-1965
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Leonard A. Coombs, 2009

did.unittitle: Arthur W. Kramer sound recording collection 1958-1965
did.abstract: Tape recordings of speeches by conservative and anti-communist lecturers.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received in 2008 from the Labadie Collection of the University of Michigan Library (donor 1180).

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

The collection contains audio tapes from which digital copies have been made. Source tapes are for staff use only. Audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Arthur W. Kramer sound recording collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

altformavail.p: Digitization: The Library has undertaken the digitization of a number of sound recordings within this collection. The resulting audio files are available for playback only in the Bentley Library Reading Room. Links to item images and additional information are available within this finding aid. Original sound recordings are only available for staff use.

bioghist.p: Arthur W. Kramer (1906-1998) was an Ypsilanti, Michigan, police officer. Beyond this, nothing is known about the origin of the collection.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains tape recordings (7" and some 5" reels) of speeches by conservative and anti-communist lecturers. Most of the tapes are dated, and are arranged by year.

accessrestrict.p: [Digitized audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.]

did.abstract: (“The Abolition of Income Taxes” and “The Proposed 23rd Amendment,” Willis E. Stone, introduction by Orville Sherwood, Grosse Pointe, Michigan.)
(“The Abolition of Income Taxes” and “The Proposed 23rd Amendment,” Willis E. Stone, introduction by Orville Sherwood, Grosse Pointe, Michigan. Conclusion of the lecture began on the first side.)

did.unittitle: Anderson lecture, Detroit, Michigan; Herbert Philbrick, “Communist Brainwashing and Cybernetics,” Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 1960 November 16

did.abstract: (Tom Anderson lecturing on the subject of federal aid and freedom, cautioning against increased government involvement in society.)
(Herbert Philbrick, Author and Lecturer, Rye Beach, New Hampshire. Former counterspy for the F.B.I., author of "I Led Three Lives," which has been dramatized on television.)

FBI counterspy Julia Brown; Cleon Skousen, Annual meeting of Michigan Farm Bureau, 1961 November 08, 1964 April 24

did.abstract: (Julia Brown introduced by Jim Downes. Topics discussed include the relationship between the Civil Rights Movement and Communism.)
(Cleon Skousen, author of "The Naked Communist" speaking on fears of Communism.)

did.unittitle: Strom Thurmond, Flint, Michigan; “Red Infiltration of National Council of Churches,” Edgar Bundy, 1961 December, 1961 October

did.abstract: (Strom Thurmond anti-Communist speeches in Flint Michigan.)
(Edgar Bundy discussing the possibility of Communist involvement of the National Council of Churches.)

did.unittitle: “Counterattack,” Bella Dodd; first and second talk, question and answer session, 1961 September 01

did.abstract: (Bella Dodd discussing fears of a coming of a World Government run by the United Nations.)
(At Counterattack Freedom School, Bella Dodd speaking on peril of the United Nations and Communism, Education and Communism.)

did.unittitle: “Communism in Education,” Bella Dodd; “Communism and Youth,” Herbert Philbrick with Ronald Reagan, George Putnam, Roy Rogers, Dale Evans, Pat Boone, 1961 August, 1961 September 01

did.abstract: (Bella Dodd discussing fears of a coming of a World Government run by the United Nations. Identical to SR-14-1.)
(Various speakers and actors discussing the fear of Communism infiltrators in the United States.)

did.unittitle: “Brainwashing,” Fred Schwarz and Father Stephen Dunker; “Communist Infiltration of Education,” Bella Dodd, Detroit, Michigan, [Undated], 1961 September 01

did.abstract: (Fred Schwarz discussing Pavlov's dogs and the implications of brainwashing in Communist infiltration. )
(Bella Dodd discussing fears of a coming of a World Government run by the United Nations. Identical to SR-14-1.)

did.unittitle: Benjamin Freedman, Washington, D.C.; Rev. McKenzie, Staffin, Rood, Detroit, Michigan, 1961, 1962 January 27

did.abstract: (Benjamin Friedman on Anti-Zionism, Anti-Communism, decrying Kennedy and Zionist organizations.)
(Multiple speakers on faith and anti-Communism.)

did.abstract: (Kellogg Center, East Lansing Michigan. Speech by Cleon Skousen, anti-Communist activist and author of "The Naked Communist.")
(Howard Kershner from Kansas and member of Herbert Hoover's "Committee Food For Small Democracies.")

“Probe,” Albert E. Burke; Captain Eddie; Detroit, Michigan; Cleon Skousen, Atlantic City, New Jersey, 1962, 1964

did.abstract: ("The Invisible Warrior" discussing Russian Communist and Guerrilla attempts at taking over America.)
(Cleon Skousen giving a speech entitled "Retreat Means Defeat" on Communist infiltration of America.)

Hoover. J. Edgar Hoover address to American Legion National Convention October 9, 1962
Radio talks by Carl McIntire; J. Edgar Hoover, 1962 October 09, 1962 October 24-27

did.abstract: (Carl McIntire, editor of the "Christian Beacon" newsletter and pastor. Speaking out against new evangelicalism and against Communism, broadcast from New Jersey.)
(Continuation of Carl McIntire radio program. McIntire discussing fears of Nikita Khrushchev's campaign to take over the world. Tape says J. Edgar Hoover, but only Carl McIntire is heard.)

did.unittitle: “Brainwashing the Ultimate Weapon,” William E, Mayer; Karl Prussion, Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1963 October 10

did.abstract: (Major William E. Mayer, Army Psychiatrist who studied Korean War Prisoners who were captured by the Chinese.)
(Karl Prussion at the Michigan League discussing Communist infiltration of the Michigan Daily.)

did.unittitle: “I was a Slave in Russia,” John Noble, Ann Arbor, Michigan; Fred Schwarz-Vincent Hallinan debate, San Francisco, California, 1963 January 05, 1963 September 15

did.abstract: (John Noble speaking on his experiences in the Soviet Union.)
(Hallinan, described as an "independent liberal, with strong left-wing tendencies" and Schwarz, "a religious conservative" debating their perspectives on Communism.)

did.unittitle: Side A: "Communist Threat from Within and Without," Robert Morris, Sacramento, Calif., June 5, 1963.
Side B: "Principles and Techniques of Anti-Communist Action," Fred Schwarz June 7, 1963
Karl Prussion, Detroit, Michigan; Karl Prussion, Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1963 October 06, 1963 October 10

did.abstract: (Tape includes speech from Robert Morris speaking on Anti-Communism. Content is not Karl Prussion.)
("Conquest by Progressive Surrender" discussing Communist infiltration of the United States. Cannot verify content is Karl Prussion.)

did.unittitle: “American Opinion Interviews,” Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1964 March 01

did.abstract: (Two unknown speakers during an interview. Discussing multiple subjects on youth and citizen-government interaction. One speaker is difficult to hear.)
